title: Can we get a rioter to explain how armor in league works?
body:
I have heard that 1 armor=1% of effect hit points against AD, but a the same time i have heard that rioters have stated that 1 armor=1% AD EHP is untrue because armor has diminishing returns...
Which is it?
From my knowledge if you have 500 armor and 2k health you have 10k EHP against AD, but that doesn't seem right. If you have 500 armor then every armor point get is only adding tiny fractions of a % in damage reduction.

The statement that EHP has no diminishing returns and the fact that armor in game has diminishing returns are contradictory. 
100 armor in game is 50% damage reduction, but 400 armor is only 80% damage reduction (approximately). Am i then being told that 100 armor=100 bonus EHP against AD AND 50% damage reduction but 400 armor=400% EHP against AD but only 80% damage reduction? Those numbers don't seem to add up. 

Can we please get a rioter to confirm if EHP has diminishing returns or not?
Now if you'll excuse me, i need to go lay down in a dark room to let my headache subside {{sticker:slayer-pantheon-rainbows}}

replies.body:
Armor and HP have no diminishing returns when examined individually. However, they DO stack with each other for a multiplicative effect.

It's not that Armor or Health becomes less efficient as you purchase more and more on top of what you already have. As you get more Health, any additional Armor you buy afterward does more to increase your survivability than it would have if you had bought the Armor without buying Health first.
Buying more and more Health is not getting any less efficient. It's making potential Armor purchases *more* efficient, which means that while 1000 health is still exactly as good as the previous 1000 health, it would have been a better idea to get some Armor instead. *This goes the other direction too!*

You do seem to understand how armor works, but you're looking at it from the wrong angle. 100 armor is 50% damage reduction, 200 armor is 67% damage reduction, 300 is 75% damage reduction, and so on, exactly as you said. It *appears* as though those numbers are increasing by less and less each time. But look at it this way; 100 armor (50% reduction) turns 1000 health into 2000 health, 200 (67%) turns it into 3000 health, 300 (75%) turns it into 4000. Every 100 armor increases your Effective HP by 100% of your Max Health.

So despite each stat being additive by itself, Health multiplies Armor, and Armor multiplies Health. If you have 100 armor and buy 500 health, you're actually increasing your EHP by 1000. If you then buy another 100 armor, that 500 health is now effectively 1500 health; exactly the same increase that you got from the first 100 armor.

**TL;DR** There's no diminishing returns. It's actually *increased* returns on every other defensive stat, which by comparison makes additional stacking of one stat, while *not less efficient*, not *as* efficient as the alternative stats, which creates the illusion of diminishing returns. You don't get any less out of buying tons and tons of health, but you would get more by buying some armor instead.

You've got the wrong idea about armor. The numbers given when you mouse over the stat tell you how much damage reduction you're getting, but it's more accurate to say that armor is increasing the amount of damage you can take before you die. Starting from 0 armor, every 1 unit of armor you get increases the amount of damage you can take (and the amount of time you can survive consistent dps) by 1%. It's perfectly linear forever, though obviously in practice it's capped by how many item slots are available.

But just because armor does NOT have diminishing returns, that doesn't mean that 6 Thornmails is a good build. Aside from the obvious waste of the unique passive on 5 of those and the lack of other useful passives from other items, it's inefficient because the health value being multiplied by all that armor is nothing more than your champion's base health.

Despite having it wrong, thinking of armor as having diminishing returns doesn't hurt you; the end result is that you still build a mix of health and resists, even if your reasoning for it is incorrect.

The main takeaway from this is a better way to think about armor and health while in-game. With the correct thought process you can know in seconds whether you'd be better served by buying more health, more armor, or just a Randuin's.

What basically occurs is you just gain HP against different damage types, so you can technically think of it all like HP in a way. If you buy 1000 HP when you already had 1000 HP, then you have 2000 HP (common sense of course), but this effectively reduces any damage taken by 50% _compared_ to when you only had 1000 HP. Buying another 1000 HP on top of that then reduces it by 67% _compared_ to when you had the original 1000 HP.

1000 HP - 500 AD = 500 HP (50% HP lost)
2000 HP - 500 AD = 1500 HP (25% HP lost, cut by 50% compared to 1k HP) 
3000 HP - 500 AD = 2500 HP (16.7% HP lost, cut by 33.4% compared to 1k HP)
4000 HP - 500 AD = 3500 HP (12.5% HP lost, cut by 25% compared to 1k HP)

Now with Armor instead of HP:

1000 HP + 0 Armor (+0.0 x Max HP) - 500 AD = 500 HP (50% HP lost)
1000 HP + 100 Armor (+1.0 x Max HP) - 500 AD = 750 HP (25% HP lost, cut by 50% compared to 0 Armor)
1000 HP + 200 Armor (+2.0 x Max HP) - 500 AD =  833 HP (16.7% HP lost, cut by 33.4% compared to 0 Armor)
1000 HP + 300 Armor (+3.0 x Max HP) - 500 AD = 875 HP (12.5% HP lost, cut by 25% compared to 0 Armor)

What if we alternated?

1000 HP + 0 Armor (+0.0 x Max HP) - 500 AD = 500 HP (50% HP lost)
2000 HP + 0 Armor (+0.0 x Max HP) - 500 AD = 1500 HP (25% HP lost)
2000 HP + 100 Armor ( +1.0 x Max HP) - 500 AD = 1750 HP (12.5% HP lost)
3000 HP + 100 Armor ( +1.0 x Max HP) - 500 AD = 2751 HP (8.3% HP lost)

You may look at this and say, diminishing returns, duh; however, like you said, HP _doesn't have diminishing returns_ and if HP doesn't have diminishing returns, then this proves that Armor and MR don't have diminishing returns either.

It's not contradictory. A lot of it comes down the the language used. There is a diminishing returns in terms of damage reduction (which is what you see on the display). There is no diminishing returns in terms of armours increase to EHP (it's static/linear at 1%). Think of it like acceleration and speed. When acceleration is linear, speed is not. EHP has no diminishing returns ( linear), damage reduction does (not linear). The reasons I disagree with the statement 'armour has diminishing returns' is because the concept of interest is not the damage reduction that is displayed. It's the amount of damage required to die - that is EHP and that has no diminishing returns. 

Now, that doesn't mean that armour is always gold efficient nor optimal. EHP relies on both resistances and HP. Shadow has a nice reply for this part. So does GaleWinUnleashed.

Nobody has posted the armor-damage reduction formula so I will.

Dmg multiplier = 100/(100+armor)

If you have 100/200/300/400 armor:

d = 100/(100+100) = 100/200 = 0.50
d = 100/(100+200) = 100/300 = 0.33
d = 100/(100+300) = 100/400 = 0.25
d = 100/(100+400) = 100/500 = 0.20

You will take a half as much damage with 100 armor, a third as much damage with 200 armor,  a quarter as much damage with 300 armor, and a fifth as much with 400 armor. Notice a pattern? Damage reduction per armor is lower the more armor you get.

Edit: To calculate your effective HP vs AD, take the reciprocol of the fraction and multiply it by your actual HP. Say, with 300 or 400 armor. 

For 300 armoe, our fraction is 1/4, and the reciprocol is 4/1, which is just 4. Multiply your actual HP by 4 to get your effective HP verses AD. If you have 2,000 actual HP, you will have 8,000 effective HP.

For 400 AD, our fraction is 1/5, and the reciprocol is 5/1, which is just 5. Therefore, multiply your HP by 5 to get your effective HP. You have 10,000 effective hp verses ad if you have 400 armor.

So, in short, it APPEARS to have diminishing returns, but it actually does not. Feel free to build 6 thornmail Rammus or Malphite.

Just for fun, if you are a Malphite with 6 thornnails, you will have 600 armor from items, plus 96 base armor at level 18, PLUS 30% bonus armor from W. That equals out to 905 armor! 

d = 100/(100+905)  = 100/1105 = 20/221 = 0.0905

The reciprocol of 20/221 is 221/20, which is 11.05

Malphite at level 18 has a base health of 2194. 11.05 times 2194 = 24,246 effective hp verses ad!! That's astounding lol. 

Let's see what happens when we replace one of the thornmails with a Warmogs.

Armor:( 500+ 96 )*1.3 = 775armor

d = 100/(100+774.8) = 100/875 = 4/35 = 0.114

Reciprocol of 4/35 is 35/4, which is 8.75. Malphite's hp at this point will be 2194 base + 800 warmogs = 2994 total hp. Multiply 2994 by 8.75 and we   get 26,198 effective HP vs ad. Astonishing!

This goes to show armor stacking is powerful, but mixing it with HP is better, even on malphite!

armor does not have diminishing returns

if you build one armor then you get one armor

armor growth rate does have diminishing returns but armor growth rate is a derivative of armor and is not the same as armor itself. Armor itself does not have diminishing returns

The formula is 

raw damage * damage modifier = total damage

where damage modifier = 100/(100+phyisical defense)

Where physical defense = the endsum of all antiphysical defenses

In the simplest terms physical defense will = armor

So the simplest form of the original formula would be

raw damage * 100/(100+armor) = total damage

or if you want to know what % of damage your armor is blocking just do 100/(100+armor) = damage modifier

Effective hp is a mental shortcut used to calculate just how tanky you are. You can calculate it with (1+armor/100) * total HP

In short, the fact that you can calculate effective hp in this way is proof that armor does not have diminishing returns or this formula would be wrong or half done. You cannot use this formula while claiming otherwise.
